repnme.cdata!: Honduras - Forests and Rural Productivity Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Forests and Rural
            Productivity Project for Honduras were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory; risk to development outcome
            was moderate; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory;
            and borrower's performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned include: there are
            inevitable complexities in pursuing objectives of poverty
            reduction and rural development through sustainable use of
            natural resources in a decentralized environment, through
            bottom-up processes. Effectively introducing and managing
            participatory processes requires a great deal of effort and
            attention on the part of the project. The cost of this
            effort, in terms of project staff time is likely to be
            significant and ought to be accompanied by above-average
            budget resources. Strengthening existing local institutions
            (e.g., community-based organization, municipal governments
            and their associated civil society institutions) and
            promoting a culture of civil society participation pays high
            dividends in terms of transparency, ownership,
            accountability and quality of project investment. This
            requires appropriate investments in strengthening local
            institutions and their social capital in order to improve
            the governance of the local decision making processes and
            ensure that they are both democratic and representative of
            local aspirations. Institution building has generally been
            identified as one area where World Bank projects have had
            only limited success. The potential for success in this area
            and for achieving institutional sustainability of project
            outcomes can be enhanced when project design and
            implementation both focus on having and implementing an
            institutional exit strategy throughout the entire project
            cycle. For complex interventions, scaling up should be
            attempted only if the pilot itself is of reasonable size and
            replicates. In establishing a system for decentralized and
            privatized extension, there should be a combination of
            private and producer organization-based technical service
            providers. The former are needed where innovation
            specialized services are required. The latter have the
            benefit of being decentralized already, and working with and
            through them builds local level capacity and creates the
            potential for more efficient expansion of the system
            locally, and across other crops and activities. Where there
            are complex institutional scenarios for project
            implementation, there is a good argument for locating
            project implementation responsibility at the policy-level
            rather than at the operational-level. Community forestry is
            a viable instrument to achieve sustainable Natural Resources
            Management (NRM) and economic development of indigenous and
            non-indigenous communities under common land property regimes.

docna.cdata!: Honduras - Forests and Rural Productivity Project

repnme.cdata!: Honduras - Forests and Rural Productivity Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Honduras Forest and Rural
            Productivity Project aims to increase the economic benefits
            and environmental services derived from forest ecosystems in
            selected low income municipalities with high agro- forestry
            potential within the project area The project has four
            components: Component 1 promotes Community Forestry.
            Activities will include: (1) subprojects comprising
            extension, technical assistance, training, and investment to
            improve the standard of living of the rural poor occupying
            forest lands; (2) applied research subprojects to
            demonstrate the benefits of improved technologies and
            strengthen the National System for Research and Technology
            Transfer (SNITTA); and (3) a training program to strengthen
            the capacity of key local actors in the implementation
            process of subprojects, including municipalities, Technical
            Service Providers (Pests), and farmer leaders (men and
            women). The component will finance community demand-driven
            subprojects (including seed capital for productive
            investment/revolving funds), applied research, consultant
            services, training and operational expenses.  Component 2
            supports Forest Management, Tenure and Conservation. Support
            will be provided to: (1) forest management planning and
            forest protection in national, municipal, communal, and
            private lands and forest management in national lands; (2)
            strengthen and expand the process of regularization of
            rights of populations living in national lands; (3)
            strengthen the management of priority protected areas and of
            the Honduras National Protected Areas System (SINAPH),
            including assistance to establish and implement a Protected
            Areas Fund tofinance protection and management expenditures
            in priority SINAPH Protected Areas; and (iv) develop and
            implement the policy and institutional reforms required to
            sustain these interventions. Component 3 finances Local
            Government & Disaster Preparedness. There are two
            subcomponents: (1) Strengthening of Local Institutions,
            providing capacity building assistance and (2) Disaster
            Preparedness, supporting the development and application of
            land use, zoning and vulnerability plans. The component will
            finance consultant services, goods, training and workshops,
            works, and operating costs. Component 4 and covers the
            administration costs of the Project Coordination Unit and
            activities related to monitoring and evaluation, technical
            studies and training as required for project implementation,
            including preparation of new investment proposals.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Forests and Rural Productivity
            Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Forests
            and Rural Productivity Project is to increase economic, and
            environmental benefits of goods and services derived from
            regional forestry ecosystems, and to generate income,
            actions, and policies conducive to rural poverty reduction.
            Likewise, the project aims at ensuring an integral and
            sustainable management of natural resources, potentially to
            minimize vulnerability to natural disasters. Although the
            project does not envisage any involuntary resettlement for
            communities living in and around protected areas, this
            resettlement plan suggests public awareness campaigns to
            inform local populations of their rights, land tenure and
            registry within the legal and regulatory framework. Measures
            to minimize adversity stipulate that: a) small and medium
            scale farmers, whose communal lands are that of municipal
            property, will be supported in obtaining property rights
            within the country's institutional framework; b)
            communities located within protected areas, or who benefit
            from natural resources, shall be governed by the
            institutional framework, which will establish adequate
            resettlement, and grievance mechanisms, should conflict
            occur; c) indigenous populations, or ethnic groups who
            benefit from natural resources within protected areas,
            following cadastre procedures, shall be granted a
            Certificate of Occupancy to protect their rights to land,
            establishing an annuity to participate in the area's
            sustainable management plan.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Forests and Rural Productivity
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
Implementation of the Forests and Rural
            Productivity Project is considered highly positive for the
            environment, for it aims at forestry, and natural habitat
            conservation, through a strengthened management of protected
            areas, which also includes the establishment of new national
            protected areas, and areas for rural productivity, based on
            the country's cadastre regulatory, and institutional
            framework. This environmental assessment sets the framework
            to ensure environmental standards, and compliance with the
            Bank's social and environmental safeguards, despite the
            positive environmental nature of the project, which has been
            classified as Category B. Mitigation measures are as
            follows. To minimize social conflicts, due to cadastre
            regularization in rural and forestry areas, loss of access
            to sustainable natural resources, of income and/or living
            standards, based on a participatory approach, and diagnosis,
            technical assistance will be provided to ensure appropriate
            mechanisms in land tenure, and communal planning.
            Communities should participate in forestry management
            programs within an institutional framework, to further
            ensure their economic benefits. To avoid soil erosion, and
            sedimentation, no new access roads will be constructed,
            instead, existing roads will be rehabilitated as needed,
            which should include appropriate drainage, based on a
            sediment control design. In addition, vegetative propagation
            should further stabilize soils, and drainage systems. No
            heavy equipment will be allowed in humid tropical forests,
            which should be protected, and only "Pinnus spp"
            may be logged. An analysis of the forestry sector will
            determine the regional forestry management, and
            implementation norms to be followed, in accordance with
            environmental standards, and strict monitoring. Only native
            species will be replanted. Capacity building and technical
            assistance in protected area management, and biodiversity
            conservation shall be provided. Infrastructure development
            will follow environmental guidelines in a case by case
            basis, based on engineering designs that comply with
            specified mitigation. While an intensified agricultural
            production will be fostered, an integrated approach will be
            followed, that includes capacity building and agricultural
            extension, particularly in soil and water conservation.
            Agrochemical products will only be available following an
            adequate training in chemical management, storage, and disposal.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Forests and Rural Productivity
            Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
Within the context of the Forests and
            Rural Productivity Project, this Indigenous Peoples Plan
            (IPP), based on the country's judicial framework, and
            surveys/censuses conducted within a participatory approach,
            specifies the guidelines to be taken during project
            implementation, concerning the indigenous, and ethnic
            populations living in the project area. It reviews their
            socioeconomic conditions, social structure, and
            socio-political aspects, in addition to land tenure, and
            income generation. Within the institutional framework, it is
            recommended to provide capacity building and technical
            assistance, particularly in river basin management, and to
            support small scale irrigation infrastructure works, so that
            local communities may profit from the project's
            economic benefits. Evaluation and follow-up procedures are
            recommended to ensure compliance with this IPP, including
            fostering populations to participate in their own funds
            management, but most importantly, tribal consensus
            highlights the need for institutional programs that fosters
            indigenous culture as a communal support process. Programs
            should further include capacity building and technical
            assistance in forest management, agro-forestry practices,
            and alternative productive activities for income generation.
